patterns: Please describe What is a Stock
responses: A Stock is an ownership in a company which can be traded in an exchange

patterns: Please describe What is a Stock Symbol
responses: A one- to four-character alphabetic root symbol that represents a publicly traded company on a stock exchange. Apple’s stock symbol is AAPL, while Walmart’s is WMT

patterns: What are the types of Stock according to Sector
responses: The Types of Stock According to Sector are: Energy, Materials, Industrials, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Health Care, Financials, IT, Telecommunication, Utilities, Real Estate

patterns: What are the types of Stocks according to market capitalization
responses: The types of Stock according to Market Capitalization are: Mega ($300 Billion+), Large ($10 Billion+), Mid ($2 Billion - $10 Billion), Small ($300 Million – $2 Billion), Micro ($50 Million - $300 Million), Nano (Below $50 Million)

patterns: Please describe What is a Broker
responses: A broker is a person who buys or sells an investment for you in exchange for a fee (a commission).

patterns: Please describe What is an Exchange
responses: An exchange is a place in which different investments are traded such as the PSE (Philippine Stock Exchange).

patterns: Please describe What is day trading
responses: The practice of buying and selling within the same trading day, before the close of the markets on that day.

patterns: Please describe What is a Sector
responses: A group of stocks that are in the same industry belong to the same sector. An example would be the technology sector, which includes companies like Apple and Microsoft.

patterns: Please describe What is a Volatility
responses: The price movements of a stock or the stock market as a whole. Highly volatile stocks are those with extreme daily up and down movements and wide intraday trading ranges.
Also called offer price, offer, asking price, or simply ask, is the amount of money a seller states they will accept.

patterns: Please describe What is a Bid
responses: The bid is the amount of money a trader is willing to pay per share for a given stock.

patterns: Please describe What is a Close
responses: Refers to the time at which a stock exchange closes to trading.

patterns: Please describe What is an open
responses: Refers to the time at which people can begin trading on a particular exchange.
The number of shares of stock traded during a particular time period, normally measured in average daily trading volume. Volume can also mean the number of shares you purchase of a given stock.
A stock's actual value is whatever someone is willing to pay. While fundamental factors influence stock prices over the long term, supply and demand rule stock prices in the short term.

patterns: Please describe What is Net Foreign
responses: Refer to the value of overseas assets owned by a nation, minus the value of its domestic assets that are owned by foreigners, adjusted for changes in valuation and exchange rates.

This is the difference between the bid and the ask prices of a stock, or the amount for which someone is willing to buy it and the amount for which someone is willing to sell it. For instance, if a trader is willing to trade XYZ stock for $10 and a buyer is willing to pay $9 for it, the spread is $1.

Often refers to the measure of the return on an investment that is received from the payment of a dividend. This is determined by dividing the annual dividend amount by the price paid for the stock. If you bought stock XYZ for $40 per share and it pays a $1.00-per-year dividend, you have a 'yield' of 2.5 percent
A portion of a company’s earnings that is paid to shareholders, or people that own that company’s stock, on a quarterly or annual basis.

patterns: Please describe What is a Portfolio
responses: A collection of investments owned by an investor makes up his or her portfolio. You can have as few as one stock in a portfolio, but you can also own an infinite amount of stocks or other securities.

patterns: Please describe What are Blue Chip Stocks
responses: The stocks behind large, industry-leading companies. Blue chip stocks offer a stable record of significant dividend payments and have a reputation of sound fiscal management.

patterns: Please describe What is a bearish market
responses: Trading talk for the stock market being in a downward trend, or a period of falling stock prices. This is the opposite of a bull market. If a stock price plummets, it’s very bearish.

patterns: Please describe What is Bullish Market
responses: When the stock market as a whole is in a prolonged period of increasing stock prices. It’s the opposite of a bear market.
Refers to a market milestone in which a stock or index reaches a greater price point than previously.
Low is the opposite of high. It represents a lower price point for a stock or index.
An investor’s bid to buy or sell a certain amount of stock or option contracts constitutes an order. You have to put an order in to buy or sell 100 shares of stock, for instance.
When an order to buy or sell has been completed, the trader has executed the transaction. If you put in an order to sell 100 shares, this means that all 100 shares have been sold.

patterns: Please describe What is Averaging Up
responses: Refers to the process of buying additional shares of a stock you already own, but at a higher price. This raises the average price that the investor pays for all the shares.

patterns: Please describe What is averaging down
responses: When an investor buys more of a stock as the price goes down.
buying and selling the same security on different markets and at different price points.

patterns: Please describe What is Annual Report
responses: A report prepared by a company that’s intended to impress shareholders. It contains tons of information about the company, from its cash flow to its management strategy.

A measurement of the relationship between the price of a stock and the movement of the whole market. If stock XYZ has a beta of 1.5, that means that for every 1 point move in the market, stock XYZ moves 1.5 points, and vice versa.

An Initial Public Offering(IPO) is the first sale or offering of a stock by a company to the public. It happens when a company decides to go public rather than remain solely owned by private or inside investors.

a term for an extremely thin spread between the bid and ask prices of a given stock. It can also refer to a situation in which a stock price gets reduced by a specific percentage for margin trades or other purposes.
A benchmark that is used as a reference marker for traders and portfolio managers.

When you use leverage, you borrow shares in a stock from your broker with the goal of increasing your profit. If you borrow shares and sell them all at a higher price point, you return the shares and keep the difference.

A margin account lets a person borrow money (take out a loan, essentially) from a broker to purchase an investment. The difference between the amount of the loan and the price of the securities is called the margin.

patterns: Please describe What is Moving Average
responses: A stock’s average price-per-share during a specific period of time is called its moving average. Some common time frames to study in terms of a stock’s moving average include 50- and 200-day moving averages.
Information on a stock’s latest trading price tells you its quote. This is sometimes delayed by 20 minutes unless you’re using an actual broker trading platform.
A rapid increase in the general price level of the market or of the price of a stock is known as a rally.

patterns: Please describe What is Share Market
responses: Any market in which shares of a particular company are bought and sold. The stock market is an example — and probably the most significant example — of a share market.

patterns: Please describe What is Pink Sheet Trading
responses: The term 'pink sheets' refers most commonly to penny stocks, which are traded at $5 per share or less. They’re also called over-the-counter stocks because that’s how they are traded.

patterns: Please describe What is Short Selling
responses: When you short-sell a stock, you borrow shares from someone else with the promise to return them at a point down the road. You then sell the stock for a profit. It’s a way to take advantage of a stock that you believe will decrease in price. After you sell short, you can buy back the shares at the lower price point and take the difference in price as your profit.

patterns: Please describe What is Risk Assesment Test
responses: Simply put, it is a test that measureas your confidence or readiness for investing. Through this test, one can be classified as an aggressive investor or a conservative one. You can actually try the this by simply typing I want to take exam
